pullRequest.body:
This PR adds some basic API lemmas for `BddAbove (range f)` (resp `BddBelow`). This is a ubiquitous side condition when working with `iInf`/`iSup` in conditionally complete lattices, so I think it's worth having.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
Thanks :tada:

bors merge

bors r-

Sorry, I thought you were done...

bors d+

:v: dupuisf can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
Canceled.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7515250248/job/20458977647)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7515250248/job/20458977534)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7515250248/job/20458977597)
Could you also replace the uses of `Set.range` by `range` where the namespaces are already open?
Can't this also be golfed using `OrderDual`?
Not easily. We need to take the dual of both `β` and `γ`, and I think the `Monotone g` hypothesis needs to be adapted. Maybe it's possible but it's easier to copy/paste.

```suggestion
  obtain ⟨C, hC⟩ := hbdd
  use C
  rintro - ⟨x, rfl⟩
  exact (h x).trans (hC <| mem_range_self x)
```

```suggestion
    (hf : BddAbove (Set.range f)) (hg : Monotone g) : BddAbove (Set.range (g ∘ f)) := by
  simpa only [Set.range_comp] using hg.map_bddAbove hf
```

Was there a reason not to use composition notation? It makes the proof easier but maybe it gets annoying to use with other parts of the library?

Yes, the version with comp notation is more annoying to use in practice. Here's an example:
```
example : BddBelow (range (fun (n : ℤ) => Int.natAbs (n + 5))) := by
  refine BddBelow.range_comp ?_ ?_
  sorry
```
Here, the refine call fails for `range_comp` defined as `BddBelow (range (g ∘ f))` but succeeds for `BddBelow (range (fun x => g (f x)))`. I see quite a few lemmas in mathlib with this problem, and having to use `change` to apply them gets tedious. I'll change it back if you don't mind.
I guess you can still use Anatole's proof after `show {the statement using \circ}`.
Yes, that's what I did.

```suggestion
    (hf : BddBelow (Set.range f)) (hg : Monotone g) : BddBelow (range (g ∘ f)) := by
  simpa only [Set.range_comp] using hg.map_bddBelow hf
```

What do you think of naming this `BddBelow.range_inv`? [BddBelow.inv](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Bounds.html#BddBelow.inv) does not insist on the order inversion, so I would say for consistency it's better not to do it here
Fair enough.

```suggestion
    BddAbove (Set.range (fun x => (f x)⁻¹)) :=
  hf.range_comp (OrderIso.inv G).monotone
```
There's a slight defeq abuse but it can't leak and it's often used already.

Also, the statement could be `BddAbove (Set.range f⁻¹)`. This may be harder to use because of inconsistent use of the pointwise notations, but on the other hand I think this is what we should converge to as a normal form, so you can decide which one you prefer
Hopefully we should be able to make a proof of this analogous to the one I suggested for `inv` using lemmas added in #9690
Good idea; I'll make the change as soon as it's done merging.
It's done now.
